name: Avoid hardcoded network resource names (JEE)
description:
This quality rule reports all artifacts that contain hardcoded network resource

- URLs (of the form file:///c:/Tmp/Folder/ or http://host.com/folder) 
- Paths (Windows absolute paths of the form c:\Tmp\Folder) 
- JDBC URL (of the form jdbc:oracle:thin:@//myhost:1521/orcl) 
- IP addresses (IPv4 format like 0.0.0.0 to 255.255.255.255) 
- JNDI lookup path
output:
List all artifacts that reference hard coded IP adresses, URL, paths
It provides the following information: 
 - Artifact full name
rationale:
Built-in resource names cause problems when the target is moved. Avoid hardcoded network resources (e.g., IP addresses, URLs, etc.)
The software initializes data using hard-coded values that act as network resource identifiers.
This issue can prevent the software from running reliably, e.g. if it runs in an environment does not use the hard-coded network resource identifiers. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.
Hard coding network resorces, server IP addresses, URL etc can expose the information to attackers. Anyone who has access to the class files can decompile them and discover the sensitive information.
Hard coding sensitive information also increases the need to manage and accommodate changes to the code
reference:
ASCRM 1.0, Automated Source Code Reliability Measure, Object Management Group.
https://wiki.sei.cmu.edu/confluence/display/java/MSC03-J.+Never+hard+code+sensitive+information
remediation: Retrieve the hardcoded IP adresses, URLs, paths from an external file located in a secure directory
alternativeName: Ensure not having hard-coded network resources names in the source files (JEE)
